title: 108_hr5118
content: The Act is titled the "Prevention of Terrorist Access to Destructive Weapons Act of 2004" and its purpose is outlined in Section 2 as findings and purpose. Congress finds that the criminal use of MANPADS, atomic weapons, and the Variola virus pose serious threats to civil aviation, public health, and national security. The last case of smallpox in the United States was in 1949, and the last naturally occurring case in the world was in Somalia in 1977. Smallpox has been eradicated globally through vaccination programs, but there are still two official repositories of the variola virus for research. The variola virus is considered dangerous and could be used by terrorists. The use of MANPADS, atomic or radiological weapons, or the variola virus against the United States poses a grave risk to national security, requiring measures to prevent unlawful activities related to these items. The Act aims to prevent the unauthorized production, acquisition, transfer, or use of dangerous weapons like MANPADS, atomic weapons, radiological weapons, and the variola virus, which could be used by terrorist organizations to attack the United States and its allies. There is no legitimate reason for individuals or companies to possess these items without government authorization. The purpose of the Act is to combat the potential use of weapons that could cause widespread harm to the United States. The Act aims to prevent the unauthorized possession of dangerous weapons that could be used to threaten national security or harm the United States economy. The Act aims to prevent the unauthorized possession of dangerous weapons that could threaten national security or harm the United States economy. SEC. 3. MISSILE SYSTEMS DESIGNED TO DESTROY AIRCRAFT. Section 2332g of Title 18, US Code prohibits the production, transfer, possession, or use of missile systems designed to destroy aircraft. The production, transfer, possession, or use of missile systems designed to destroy aircraft is prohibited under Section 2332g of Title 18, US Code. This includes devices or parts used for assembling or fabricating rockets or missiles. Conduct by the United States or its agencies, as well as conduct under contract terms, are excluded from this prohibition. The jurisdiction of the United States under Section 2332g of Title 18, US Code includes offenses that occur in or affect interstate or foreign commerce, offenses committed by US nationals outside the country, offenses against US nationals abroad, and offenses against US-owned property. Conduct under contract terms with the US or its agencies is exempt from this prohibition. The criminal penalties for violating subsection (a) of Section 2332g of Title 18, US Code include fines up to $2,000,000 and imprisonment for a minimum of 30 years or life. Additionally, using, attempting, or conspiring to use any items described in subsection (a) can result in a fine of up to $2,000,000 and life imprisonment. The criminal penalties for violating subsection (a) of Section 2332g of Title 18, US Code include fines up to $2,000,000 and imprisonment for a minimum of 30 years or life. If the death of another results from the violation, the person can be fined up to $2,000,000 and punished by death or life imprisonment. The term 'aircraft' is defined as in section 40102(a)(6) of title 49, United States Code. SEC. 4. ATOMIC WEAPONS. Section 92 of the Atomic Energy Act of 1954 is amended to include prohibitions on knowingly exporting, acquiring, receiving, using, possessing, or threatening to use any atomic weapon. The jurisdiction of the United States applies if the offense occurs in or affects interstate or foreign commerce, is committed by a U.S. national outside the country, or is against a U.S. national. The Atomic Energy Act of 1954 is amended to include prohibitions on offenses committed against U.S. nationals outside the country or on U.S. property, aiding or abetting such offenses, or conspiring to commit them. The Atomic Energy Act of 1954 is amended to include harsh penalties for violations, including fines up to $2,000,000 and imprisonment for not less than 30 years or life. The use of atomic weapons in violation of the act can result in life imprisonment. If a violation results in death, the offender may face a fine, death penalty, or life imprisonment. SEC. 5. RADIOLOGICAL DISPERSAL DEVICES. Section 2332h of title 18, United States Code, prohibits the production, acquisition, possession, or use of radiological dispersal devices designed to release radiation dangerous to human life. Section 2332h of title 18, United States Code prohibits the production, acquisition, possession, or use of radiological dispersal devices. This subsection exempts conduct authorized by the United States or under its authority, or pursuant to a contract with the United States. Jurisdiction for prohibited conduct includes offenses affecting interstate or foreign commerce, committed by a U.S. national outside the country, against a U.S. national abroad, or against U.S. property. Section 2332h of title 18, United States Code prohibits the production, acquisition, possession, or use of radiological dispersal devices. Offenses include those committed against U.S. property, aiding or abetting others in committing the offense, or conspiring to commit the offense. Criminal penalties include fines up to $2,000,000 and imprisonment for not less than 30 years or life. Any person who uses, attempts, or conspires to use radiological dispersal devices in violation of the law may face a fine of up to $2,000,000 and life imprisonment. If the violation results in death, the penalty may include a fine of up to $2,000,000, death penalty, or life imprisonment. SEC. 6. VARIOLA VIRUS. Chapter 10 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include a new section, 175c, regarding the variola virus. It is unlawful to produce, engineer, acquire, possess, import, export, or use the variola virus, with exceptions for the Secretary of Health and Human Services. Jurisdiction applies if the offense affects interstate or foreign commerce, or if committed outside the U.S. by a U.S. national. The new section 175c of title 18, United States Code, prohibits the production, acquisition, possession, import, export, or use of the variola virus, with exceptions for the Secretary of Health and Human Services. Jurisdiction applies if the offense affects interstate or foreign commerce, is committed by a U.S. national outside the U.S., or involves property owned by the U.S. Criminal penalties include fines for violations or attempts to violate the law. The new section 175c of title 18, United States Code, prohibits the production, acquisition, possession, import, export, or use of the variola virus. Criminal penalties include fines up to $2,000,000 and imprisonment for violations. Life imprisonment or death penalty may apply in certain circumstances. The new section 175c of title 18, United States Code, prohibits the possession, production, acquisition, import, export, or use of the variola major virus containing over 85% of its gene sequence. SEC. 7 amends Section 2516(1) of title 18, United States Code to include additional sections for interception of communications. SEC. 8 amends Section 2332B(G)(5)(B) of title 18, United States Code. SEC. 8 amends Section 2332b(g)(5)(B) of title 18, United States Code by adding provisions related to missile systems, radiological dispersal devices, variola virus, and prohibitions governing atomic weapons. AMENDMENTS TO SECTION 1956(C)(7)(D) OF TITLE 18, UNITED STATES CODE. Section 1956(c)(7)(D), title 18, United States Code, is amended to include new sections related to variola virus, missile systems, and radiological dispersal devices. Additionally, the amendment expands the list of felony violations to include section 92 of the Atomic Energy Act of 1954. SEC. 10. Export Licensing Process amended to include new sections related to missile systems designed to destroy aircraft, atomic weapons, radiological dispersal devices, and variola virus. SEC. 11. Clerical amendments made to Chapter 113B of title 18, United States Code. The table of sections for chapter 10 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include new items related to missile systems designed to destroy aircraft, radiological dispersal devices, and variola virus.
